gen:ReportedAttribute.com:Text: Goal 10. Reduce inequalities within and across countries
10.1 By 2030, gradually and sustainably achieve income growth for the poorest 40% of the population at a rate faster than the national average income
10.1.1 b) Growth rate of household expenditure per capita for the entire population
Burundi Institute of Statistics and Economic Studies (ISTEEBU)
NDAYISENGA Modest
Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring Service "SESSSP"
Head of the “Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring” department
1156 BUJUMBURA
ndayimode2010@gmail.com
It is the average annual growth rate of real per capita consumption of the distribution of household income in a country
Percentage
Household surveys
The data are collected by carrying out surveys type ECVMB
ISTEEBU
ISTEEBU is responsible for compiling the data allowing the calculation of this indicator at the national level
ISTEEBU is the body recognized by the Burundian government for the collection, processing and dissemination, after validation, of official statistics helping in planning and decision-making
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the level of expenditure over a year and allows a comparison to be made
It is the ratio between the variation in household expenditure per capita during a given year compared to household expenditure per capita in the previous year,
Survey data is validated at two levels: internal validation and extended validation
The indicator is available at national level
ECVMB 2013-2014 report and QUIBB 2006 survey
Goal 10. Reduce inequalities within and across countries

10.2 By 2030, empower all people and promote their social, economic and political integration, regardless of age, gender, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or their economic or other status
10.2.1. Number of returnees
MIFPDL
NTERIMBERE Christine
MIFPDL statistical service
SDG focal point at MIFPDL
1156 BUJUMBURA
nterichristine@yahoo.fr
It is the number of Burundian refugees abroad who have returned
without unit
Administrative data
Data is collected from administrative sources
The probable date of the next collection will be 2020
MIFPDL
The compilation of data for the calculation of this indicator is made by the statistical and planning service of the MIFPDL
The statistics and planning departments of the ministries are responsible for compiling data from their ministries for the calculation of indicators at the secoriel and national level.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the state of security, which favors the massive return of refugees
It is interesting to know that repatriation is voluntary, conditioned or forced.
Sum of the refugee population outside the country who returned
Data from administrative sources are most often validated by the Technical Committee for Statistical Information (CTIS), after internal validation.
The indicator is available at national level
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
MIFPDL annual report
Goal 10. Reduce inequalities within and across countries
10.4 Adopt policies, particularly in the budgetary, salary and social protection fields, in order to gradually achieve greater equality
10.4.1 Share of labor in GDP, including wages and social transfers
Burundi Institute of Statistics and Economic Studies (ISTEEBU)
NDAYISENGA Modest
Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring Service "SESSSP"
Head of the “Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring” department
1156 BUJUMBURA
ndayimode2010@gmail.com
It is the total compensation of employees and social transfers made, expressed as a percentage of GDP, that is a measure of total output for a given reference period.
Percentage
Household surveys or administrative data
Data are collected by carrying out ECVMB type surveys / daily data from national accounts
ISTEEBU
ISTEEBU is responsible for compiling the data allowing the calculation of this indicator at the national level
ISTEEBU is the body recognized by the Burundian government for the collection, processing and dissemination, after validation, of official statistics helping in planning and decision-making

The indicator provides information on the relative share of production that is paid as compensation to employees compared to the share paid to capital in the production process for a given reference period

The share of labor in GDP calculated solely on the basis of compensation of employees underestimates the proportion of accumulated GDP in relation to total employment, because it does not include the labor income of the self-employed.
Total compensation of employees in relation to gross domestic product, expressed as a percentage
Survey data is validated at two levels: internal validation and extended validation
The indicator is available at national level
ISTEEBU, Survey on the living conditions of Burundian households (ECVMB) 2013-2014, National accounts of 2014
Goal 10. Reduce inequalities within and across countries

10.b Stimulate official development assistance and financial flows, including foreign direct investment, to states most in need, in particular least developed countries, African countries, small states developing islanders and landlocked developing countries, in accordance with their national plans and programs

10.b.1 Total amount of resources allocated to development, by recipient country and donor and type of contribution (official development assistance, foreign direct investment and others) (in millions of USD)
Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
Emmanuel NIYONKURU
statistical service of the Ministry of Trade, Industry and Tourism
SDG focal point at MCIT
emmanuelniyonkuru20@yahoo.com
Total amount of resources allocated to development, by recipient and donor country and type of contribution include official development assistance, other official flows and private flows.
Administrative data
data collected daily
every year
annually
OECD
The statistics and planning departments of the ministries are responsible for compiling data from their ministries for the calculation of indicators at the national level.
The indicator is relevant because it reports it quantifies the overall spending that donors provide to developing countries.
Completeness in data collection is difficult to achieve
The sum of official and private flows from all donors to developing countries.
Internal validation and by the technical committee for statistical information (CTIS)
Data are available at national level
OECD report

Goal 10. Reduce inequalities within and across countries
10.a Implement the principle of special and differential treatment for developing countries, in particular least developed countries, in accordance with World Trade Organization agreements
10.a.1 Proportion of tariff lines affected by imports from least developed countries and developing countries benefiting from duty free
Proportion of total number of tariff lines (in percentage) applied to products imported from least developed and developing countries
The indicator is calculated as the average share of national tariff lines duty free
Not available
Goal 10. Reduce inequalities within and across countries
10.c By 2030, reduce the transaction costs of migrant remittances to below 3 percent and eliminate channels of remittances costing more than 5 percent
10.c.1 Costs of remittances in proportion to the amount transferred
The amount deducted from the transfers made, set by the BRB according to the amount transferred,
Ratio between the sum of all the amounts received following the money transfers made to the total of the transfers
Not available
